text.p: These are the leading stories in the Sarajevo press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Sarajevo university students rally in Sarajevo, protesting against difficult living conditions, new teaching programs and payments for medical services.
- The speech by the U.S. State Secretary, Madeleine Albright, proved that Americans do not intend to give up their investments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, newspaper commentary says.

- Kresimir Zubak, a Bosnian Croat presidency member, said at the meeting of Croat community Herceg-Bosna that he favoured a cultural and humanistic nationalism in order to protect the human rights of Croats, but at the same time the Croats should give positive signals and respect the rights of minorities.
- Interests of the Bosnian Croats have been protected even before, so there was no need to create Croat community Herceg-Bosna, Bosnian oposition party leaders say in response to Zubak's remarks.
- The partition of Bosnia and Herzegovina would be an extremely dangerous and a potentially bloody process, said Carl Bildt, international High Representative to Bosnia.

- The Moslem-Croat federation and Bosnian Serb entity have payed $6.4 million of the $12.4 million gas debt to the Russian supplier and it is alleged that international community will settle the outstanding $6 million, the newspaper says.
- One boy died and one lost his legs after stepping into a minefield in a Sarajevo suburb over the weekend, hospital doctors said. -- Sarajevo newsroom +387-71-663-864
